bibl.title: Hisayo Kuwahara v. Henry M. White. Depositions of J.H. Galbraith and R. Ode
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Petition of Sakutaro Kuwahara for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Depositions of J.H. Galbraith and R. Ode, witnesses for Petitioner
Depositions of J.H. Galbraith and R. Ode, witnesses for Petitioner.
In the Matter of the Petition of Sakutaro Kuwahara for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
J.H. Galbraith, being first duly sworn and cautioned, on oath deposes as follows.
Q State your name, residence and occupation?
A Age 29, superintendent Eatonville Lumber Company, residence Eatonville, Washington.
Q How how have you been superintendent of this mill?
A About ten years.
Q Were you such superintendent in 1914?
A Yes, I was superintendent and time keeper both at that time.
Q Do you know Sakutaro Kuwahara?
A Yes, I know him.
Q When, if ever, did he begin to work for the company?
A December 11, 1914.
Q How do you fix this date?
A By the time book.of the company.
Q Have you that time book here?
A Yes.
Q Is that time book in your own handwriting?
A Yes.
Q This book is the regular time book of the company?
A Yes sir.
Q And the name of S. Kuwahara appears in it on page 21?
A Yes sir, of the time book No. 3.
Q In your own handwriting?
A Yes sir.
Q Do you know that the petitioner in this case is the man whose name appears in the time book which you have just produed and identified?
A Yes, I do.
Q Has he worked for you continuously since December, 1914?
A Yes, except three or four months in 1918.
Q What have been his average earnings per month for the past two years?
A He will average around $150.00.
J.H. Galbraith
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 31st day of January, 1920.
H. V. Abel
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
R. ODE, being first duly sworn and cautioned, on oath deposes as follows.
Q What is your name, residence and occupation?
A R. Ode. I live at Eatonville. I am Japanese foreman for the Eatonville Lumber Company.
Q How long have you been such foreman?
For eleven years.
Q Do you know S. Kuwahara, the petitioner in this case?
A Oh yes, I know him.
Q How long have you known him?
A I have known him since he started to work at the plants of the Eatonville Lumber Company.
Q Do you know that he began here December 11, 1914?
A Yes.
Q Did you hire him to come here?
A Yes.
Q Where did he come from to go to work here?
A Tacoma, from the gardens just outside of Tacoma, Ohashi's Washington Gardens.
Q Do you know how long Kuwahara had been in the United States before he came to work under you for the Eatonville Lumber Company?
A About a year as near as I can say.
Q Do you know that he is the man whose wife has been trying to land in the United States since last September?
A I do.
R. Ode
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 31st day of January, 1920.
H.V Abel
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
United States of America
Western District of Washington
County of King.
ss.

I, H. V. Abel, a notary public in and for the State of Washington, duly commissioned, qualified and sworn, do hereby certify that the above depositions of J.H. Galbraith and R. Ode were taken before me and adduced to writing by myself at Eatonville, in the County of Pierce, in said Western District of Washington, on the 31st day of January 1920, at 11 o'clock a.m., in pursuance of the notice hereto annexed; I, H.V. Abel, being substituted for L. A. Michelson, the notary public named in said notice, by reason of the absence of said L. A. Michelson and his inability to attend; that the above named witnesses, before examination, were sworn to testify the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, and that the said depositions were carefully read to each of said witnesses and then subscribed by him.
H. V. Abel
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington.
Dated at Eatonville, Washington, on the 31st day of January A. D. 1920.
